TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1905.

div.head: EGYPT-OR UTOPIA.
div.p: While we cordially welcome the interest which is now being taken at home in Egypt and things Egyptian, it must be confessed that there are certain drawbacks to this attitude, especially when it tends to interference in matters which can only be competently dealt with by those who have gained a profound local knowledge of the country and its people. Egypt is far more liable than any other Oriental country to arouse the platonic passions of that class of busybody whose characteristics have been embodied by Mr. Kipling in "Padgett M. P." And as Cairo develops more and more into an Oriental Brighton during the winter months, there, must necessarily be a growing number of estimable persons, who, inspired by only a superficial acquaintance with the conditions of Egyptian life, return to England. determined to air their pet panaceas for the. betterment of the land in Parliament or the Press. However well-intentioned they may be, their efforts must, in many cases, do positive harm by stirring up that considerable section of the population of the British Isles who belong to the genus "crank" to make mis chievous attempts to hamper the work of Anglo-Egyptian Administration. A suggestive sample of these tactics occurred in a recent issue of the "Manchester Guardian," a correspondent of which paper in Vairo ventilated a number of Egyptian grievances, con-- cluding with the following sentence:- "When it is no longer possible to see Arabic children in Cairo raking the rubbish heaps in the streets for their daily food, then it will be time to declare that British officialism in Egypt is imbued with those high aims, the absence of which called from the lips of an English 'bishop the reproach against Cairo as being the grave of the soul."

The statements of this gentleman called forth an article from the editor of the "Guar dian," who indulged in these remarks with all the sententiousness befitting the occasion - "Now, that we have shaken off some of the internationaal fetters on our rule, our respon sibility for these things has become more direct and individual. It cannot be too clearly understood that no administrative clockwork has yet been invented that will go for ever. It cannot be wound up once and for all; there must be steady and continuous interest in the mechanism of government if disaster is to be avoided. English people have never, since the fighting stopped, taken a direct interest in Egyptian affairs in that way, and still less in the welfare of the Egyptian. Our correspondent points out some of the dangers of this indiffe rence. When self-government is conceded the danger is reduced to a minimum, and the policy of non-interference becomes political virtue. But we have not provided ourselves with that safeguard. The machinery of government in Egypt is still almost entirely. English, and if anything goes wrong with it England will suffer the consequences."

The sentiments conveyed in this passage. are so excellent as to partake of the nature of truisms, but they are entirely vitiated by the underlying fallacy that Egypt can be benefited by interference from England. What can parliamentary or official interference from home do to prevent "Arab children in Cairo raking the rubbish heaps in the streets for their daily bread " If the views of such persons as the correspondeht of our Manchester contemporary gained acceptance, the grumblers would soon find out to their cost that the distant and illinformed King Stork was much worse to deal with than the local King Log, whatever the faults of the latter may be. If such a policy is pursued to its logical conclusion, and the faddists obtain a hearing through their im portunity and the weakness of the houte authorities, the result will be as disastrous: as was "la politique des rattachements" to Algeria, where the powers of the Governor- General were utterly undermined by interference from Paris. As long as Lord Cromer remains this tendency will be counteracted, but it may become a really serious danger to Egypt in the future. Egyptian development should, and must, proceed on the lines of local, by which we mean not only native but resi dent. European, self government, and all attempts to invoke interference from England as a "Deus ex machina" to bring about a Nilotic Utopia must be most strenuously resisted, for it is a mischievous and unstatesmanlike policy, and runs counter to the entire system on which. the substantial fabric of British influence has been everywhere built up.

div.p: There was # demonstration in the Mal Theatre bere last night, men crying "Down with the autocracy and making use of persona învectives against the Tur. The demonstrators were finally ejected, and the performance i continued.

div.head: AMERICAN ARBITRATION. THE PRESIDENT AND SENATE.

div.p: President Roosevelt and the Senate have reached ad acute state of disagreement concerning the arbitration treaties which Mr. Hay has laboriously concluded with Japan, Great Britain, and syemal other European Powers. In spite of strong pressure on the part of Mr. Rooreveit, the Senate inserted an amendment in the treaties Securg to it the right to intervene belore any question is submittest w arbitration. In consequence, Mr. Roosevelt has resolved to drop the treaties altogether,
Public opinion, apparently, endorsey the action of the Suuate. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE HUNGARIAN CRISIS. AN HISTORICAL EVENT:

div.p: The Emperor yesterday received Herr Kos. suth in connection with the Hungarian crisis. It was a notable bistorical event as it was his first entrance to the Palace to my homage to the Emperor who bad condemned his father to death. (Reuter.)

div.head: CATTLE PLAQUE..
div.p: During the week ending Satunlay last, 7 deaths from bovine typhus were reported throughout Egypt. During the corresponding week in 1904 5,949 deaths were notified. Since the beginning of the epidemic the total number of deaths is 146 710.

div.head: NEW CATHEDRAL FOR CAIRO.-
div.p: The scheme for the erection of a Maronite Cathedral at Cairo bas taken definite shape and L E. 10,000 has already been subscribed. Mgr. Darian, the Maronite Archbish p. Chakour Pasha, Abdullah Bey Sfer, and many other Syrian notables, are heartily supporting the scheme.

div.head:
A RACE OF ARTIS IS.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir, I send a few of the smaller stones from the desert, which I think you have not seen, and for which I hope I may claim your adiniration. What, sir, would not gott or I give for that touch of hand and truth of eye ! Look at the wonderful skill with I which they have been carved, repeating again

and again the same idea, but almost always with the distinctive touch of the individual worker,--just as in the pretty attractive cloth I word of the Kabyle women, the pattern is not copied or mechanically repeated, but each worker follows an instinct of her own. And so it was with this old stone race. With some exceptions, some types ronghly executed-perhaps of the earlier time, for it! was over an immense space of time that they worked, -- and some few that merely repro dnced the conventional pattern, the mass of the stones bear constant witness to the free play of band and imagination. What gifts this desert people bad i One may donbt--and I am not forgetting the story of Greece, which wa- different in its kind if the world has ever yet produced a race with such an artistic sense 1-o widely distributed--perhaps in Japan 'you have had the nearest approach to it. In the artistic fancies of both ruces - the love of the quaint and grotesque-the mixture of human and demon-yet with a certain self-restraint, the half extravagance kept within the limits of sobriety--you feel as if there were common elements--as if the two races had shared some of the same gifts. I should like to send a tow examples to Tokio for our Japanese friends to pass judgment upon.

And now, sir, how goes it with my friends, the learned babes 1 Have they mended their little wayward fashions, and grown in wisdom and stature! Or is A.B.C. still the same sal trial, as it was, to their rebel souls 1 Do they Ixtill pont and sulk in their eyrtier? Do they still cry "can't, shan't, won't” while the little fists are doubled up in the little eyes and the little
feet stawp upon the flxer? Was there ever sich Ja hullabaloo and piece of work in the nursery
all about learning A.B.C., which sooner or later must be learned. There is no prissible escape from it. No amount of shan't and won't

can help them. Their fate is inexorably I written. And never was there a prettier, pleasanter, more attractive A.B.C. for a babe to learn--an A.B.C. that sh-uld never have cost a tear oz a whimper! And as soon as they once humble the haughty little souls- just a touch wanted of the penitent's redeeming grace--and set themselves with goodwill to the task, what delight they will find in it, what revelations are waiting for them! But I must not take up too much of your space. At
Rome, Trieste, Athens, and again at AlexJandria, I found after some little hunting plenty

of traces of the same race. The stone was I much less favorable, ant the work consequently much rougher ; but the lealing types were the same. Some day we ought to be able to trace with considerable exnotness the march of this great people--for really great they | were. You cannot live amongst their work, and with hold your admiration from them.I am, eto,

div.head:
ROYAL VISIT TO KHARTOUM.
REVIEW OF TROOPS.
div.p: A review of all the troops in the station I was held this morning on the parade ground at| Khartoum. At 8 o'clock H.R.H. the Duchess of Connanght, with the Princesses, accompanied by Lady Wingate, arrived ina landau at the Royal| stand. A few minntes later H.R. H. the Duke, | accompanied by H.E. the Sirlar and Governor| General, General Sir J. Maxwell, and the staff, followed on the parade-ground, and the Royal Standard was at once boisted near the enclosure. | After the inspection, the troops began to file past his H.R.H., performing the various evolutions, the Rifle Brigade being specially smart and showing they had marched over Sudan sands once before. The cavalry, and notably the artillery, appear to bave been I quite up to the mark, and H.R.H. was pleased to express his entire satisfaction with the bearing of the troops and the evolutions effected.

I learn that the Duke of Connaught expressed the opinion that trousers for the native troups, shaped Zouave fashion, would perhaps be more suitable for this climate than the ordinary trou-ers now in use.
In the after on, the Royal party, accompanied by the whole staff, crossed over on a visit to Omdurman.

In the evening there was a military tattoo in front of Government baildings, at which the Royal party were present. Bimbashi Franklin, director of mu-io, was bonored with a few words of thanks from H. R. H. for his services on the occasion. ROYAL PARTY AT DIVINE SERVICE.
Khartoum, February 5.
The Royal party attended divine service this morning in the temporary church room in the Palace.

div.head: VISIT TO GORDON COLLEGE.
div.p: T. R. H. the Duke and Duchess of Con. naught, with the Princesses, and accompanied by H. E. the Governor General, Lady Wingate, and snite, visited Gordon College to-day and then drove round the town of Khartoum. The natives turned out and gave the Royal party a hearty greeting. The annual regatta took | place in the afternoon in front of the Palace, and at 10.30 p.m. the Royal party left for the North. I may mention that the police arrange ments throughout the Royal visit were perfect.

div.head: ASSOUAN DAM VISITED.
div.p: The Dake and Duchess of Connaught arriv. ed at Assouan this moruing and will visit the dam in the afternoon accompanied by Sir Willinn Garstin, Mr. A. L. Webb, Mr. Clowes, and Mr. Macdonald.
The R val party will leave Luxor on Thursday by a special train leaving at 6.50 p.m. which will bring them to Cairo at 9.10 a.m. ou Friday.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Today H. H. the Khedive visited the Mosque at Koubbeh for prayer on the opening of Kourban Beyram. Salvoes of 21 guns were fired from the Citadel and at Abbassieh on the arrival and departure of his Highness.

Yesterday afternoon, his Highness received Ally Pasha Yaghen, Governor of Cairo, and all the principal functionaries or notables who received promotion or decorations on the occasion of the anniversary of H. H.'s accession.

div.head: GENERAL STOESSEL AT SUEZ.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Australien," by which Gen. Stoessel is a passenger, is due to arrive at Suez to-morrow at 10 a.m.

div.head: PLAGUE ON STEAMER.
div.p: The Austrian Lloyd 8.S. "Imperator," from Bombay, arrived at Suez yesterday. Owing to her having landed a case of plagne at Aden, she was put in quarantine at this port, and after being disinfected entered the Canal in quarantine. Passengers for Suez were conveyed to Moses' Wells to purge two days' quarantine

div.head: EXPORT OF GUM ARABIC.
div.p: Daring the month of December last, 1,031,614 kilus of gum arabic, valued at LE.23,217, were exported from Egypt. In the same month of 1903 the experts were 574,359 kilos, of the value of L.E.12,967, showing an increase in 1904 of 457,255 kilos, value LE 10,250.

During the year 1904, the exports show increases of 1,989,571 kilos in weight and of LE. 11,394 in amount as compared with 1903, the respective figures being as follows:- 1904, 10,402,054 kilos, value L.E.234,060 ; 1903, 8.412,483 kilos, value L.E.192,666.

Of the above, the export to England and her Mediterranean possessions was 2.220,528 kilos, valno LE 49,960; Germany, 1,740,096 kilos, value LE. 39,159 ; Austria-Hungary, 702,815 kilos, value L.E.15,810 ; France and Algeria, 2,711,811 kilos, value L.B. 60,990; Italy, 286,086 kilos, value LE 6,424 ; Turkey, 12,303 kilos, value L.E.269; America, 1,438, 424 kilos, value L.E.32,364, and to other countries 1,290,992 kilos, value L.E.29,084,

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S TRIP.
VISIT TO KENEH.
div.p: Keneh, Saturday. . Lord and Lady Cromer, accompanied by Lady Beatrice Thyone, arrived at keneh by steamer at 1 p.m, to-day. Among those awaiting their arrival were the Moudir, the SubMoudir, all the heads of the Government de partments, the consular agents, omdehs, sheikhs, and a guard of honor.

As the steamer accosted the landing stage, I Lord Cromer stepped out and sbook hands with the Moudir, who introduced a number of those present to his lordship. On Lord Cromer asking if anyone could speak English, the SubMoudir replied in the affirmative, and his lordship proceeded to thank the gathering for their reception, the Sub-Moudir acting as interpreter. Lord Cromer said he regretted he bad no time to visit the town, as he was in al burry to leave for the South

The steamer remained at the landing stage for some time ooaling and at 3.30 sailed for Kous, where the party will stop for the night. On the following morning (Sunday) the steamer will leave at 6 o'olook for Mataang direct and will make another stay there for the night. Erom Mataana the distinguished party proceed to Silwa, from which place they will go to Kom Orabo, where they will remain three hours. Leaving Kom Ombo they will reach Assouan on the afternoon of Tuesday, the 14th | inst. Lord and Lady Cromer expect to be back in Cairo on the 22nd inst.

div.head: THE LATE JUDGE KEILEY.
div.p: The funeral of the late Judge A. M. Kelley, formerly judge of the Mixed Courts of Egypt, who was accidentally killed in the streets of Paris, took place at Notre-Dame on Saturday, February 4. The American Consul-General was present.

Owing to illness, neither the judge's son-inlaw, Captain Hall, nor his daughter were able to be present, but the family was represented by Mr. Arnold Hall and Miss Hall, who came | from England to assist at the ceremony. -

A correspondent writes as followa to the "New York Herald” (Paris) :-I feel that the death of so well- known an American as Judge A. M. Keiley deserves a record. In your edition of Saturday, January 28, I found a short paragraph, ovpied from a French paper, stating that a well-dressed man, about sixty years of age, had been knocked down by a delivery van in the place de la Concorde the day before, and had been carried to the hospital, where he died that night. In his pocket was found a card bearing the name and address of Judge Keiley, 49, Dover-street, Piccadilly-nothing more,

Jndge Keiley was a man well known at home and abroad. He had at various times Atted several publio offices in his native city, vit., Louisville, Ky, and for many years had represented the United States in the Mixed Courts of Egypt. He lived in Alexandria until his wife died, two or three years ago, when he resigned his position and went to London, to be near a married daughter

Judge Keiley was a man of unusual attainments; he knew the classies as he did the alphabet ; not only spoke half a dozen modern languages, but know their literature as well. He know all good things and loved them. He could tell a story better than the next man, let him tell it never so well, and what is more, could appreciate the point of the other fellow's story. He was liberal, broad-minded, tenderhearted, full of sympathy for suffering : genial and warm-hearted. He was a loyal, staunch friend, and I, who only knew him casually, as it were, feel that I shall not soon look upon his like again.

div.head: A PROPOS DE L'EAU.
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur

de "l'Egyptian Gazette." On fait grand bruit en ce moment, touchant la pollution des eaux que nous vend fort cher "T'Alexandria Water Company Limited" et ce n'est point la première fois que l'on crie que l'eau est contaminée.
Après constatation des faits les services 88nitaires ne préconisent aucun système pour stériliser les conduita et assurer enfin une enu moins chargée de microbes.

Si les dits services poulaient prendre la peine d'analyser l'eau du Mahmoudieh chaque jour et si le résultat de ce petit travail était communiqué au public, celui-ci serait fort surpris d'apprendre quelle quantité considé. rable de microbes il absorbe quotidiennement,
Quant au canal de dérivation qui alimente la Compagnie des Eaux, il est installé dans toutes les conditions requises pour être contaminé en son entier parcours.
En effet, dans tous les alentours du dit canal, il n'y a pas une fosse d'aisances qui soit imperméable et cimentée conformément aux règlements sanitaires.

D'autre part, le service Maritime et Quarantenaire ne fait aucune objection quant à la fourniture de cette eau pour l'approvisionnement des navires et ne prend aucune mesure pour leur procurer de l'eau saine. Le dernier congrès sanitaire de Venise s'est pourtant 00enpé un tantinet de cette question primordiale mais ici, au pays nilotique, la consigne est et sera encore longtemps de dire : Malesch.

div.head: CONDITION. OF HELOUAN. NO GOVERNMENT SUPPORT.
div.p: * Helouan, February 12. An important meeting of the Municipal Commissioners of Helouan has been held at the Gouvernorat under the presidency of H. E. the Governor of Cairo. There were present the Tanzim delegate, Mr. Cartis, the Sanitary Department delegate, Dr. Dryer, and the four elected representative members of the town, M. Felix Suares, Hussein Bey Youssef, Mahmoud Fehmy Pasha, and Dr. A. J. M.| Bentley. | The question of the condition and wanta of the town of Helouan came before the meeting, After some remarks from M. Suares, Hussein Bey Youssef, and Mahmoud Febmy Pasha, on the unsatisfactory condition of the town and the miserable financial dole voted to the Commission, Dr. Bentley addressed the Council as

follows. | Your Excellency, - You may remember that at our last meeting I presented you with & petition from the inhabitants of the town of Helouen aoking that it might be read and considered by th: Council hefore presenting it to the Government for their consideration. This your Excellency did not see fit? to do, and the only course open to the inhabitants was to go with it direct to the chiefs of the Ministries interested, which petition was later on published in several of the newspapers of Bgypt. This petition, I hear on good authority, was not unfavorably received by the heads of tho various departments concerned. The petition, I may call to your mind, dealt with the following points :(i). The railway service ; (ü). The state of the roads and condition of the water supplied for drinking ; (iii). The constitution of the Local Commission ; (iv). The expenditure of the revenue derived from local taxation.--The Railway (i) is now in the possession of the Delta Light Railway Company and they have promised to carry out certain and, we believe, efficient reforms. The matter of the drinking water and the roads (ii) concerns the Tanzim Department. The allocation of the revenue (iv) derived from Helonan is a financial matter and concerns the Ministry of Finance. The carrying out of (ü), which is so urgently required, is

large matter, and it is absolutely impossible to deal with it satisfactorily with the small amount of money allowed to this Commission. (iii The constitution of the Commission is essentially an anomaly s elected partly by public vote to carry out reforms, ithasabsolutely no power to accomplish them. If suggestions are made to the Commission and they are not carried out, the publie regard the failure as being due to its not having the power to im prove, it still has to bear the blame. I propose, therefore, that in the best interests of Helouan. and with a due regard to the dignity of this Council, that the Municipal affairs of the town be placed again in the hands of the Goverament, which alone is able to carry out those reforms so necessary for the well-being of the town. This Commission has doubtless done excellent work in its time, the Tanzim officials connected with it have always been willing to do what they could for the improvement of the town, but owing to the rapidly increasing importance of Helouan and its neigh bourhood, and the urgent and large reforma needed, it is time that the present system, with its very limited powers, should be abolished, and that the municipal affairs should be placed in the hands of the Government, which alone has the power to efficiently carry them out I appeal to your sense of duty not to place any obstacle in the way, but rather to sink all differences and personal feelings for the wellbeing of the town of Helovan, and I further beg to suggest that to facilitate matters this Council should delegate three or more of its members to consult with the Government to ascertain ita views on this matter.

The president, in replying, stated that he had received official information that the Finance Ministry had refused to sanction any further aid to Helovan or to grant money to allow more water for the roads and trees. The tour elected representative members there upon tendered their resignation in a body, as a protest against the Government decision. * Later on they were, however, induced by the president to withdraw their resignations conditionally on his Excellenoy på mising to bring their protest before the proper authorities. They, however, expressed very decided views to his Excellency on the uselessness of holding | further meetings under existing circum stances.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The King has been pleseed to give and grant unto Robert Lang Anderson, Faq., Manager of the Aboukir Landa Reclamation Company, His Majesty's Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Third Class of the Imperial | Ottoman Order of the Osmanish, conferred | upon him by H.H. the Khedive of Bgypt, authorised by H.I.M. the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered by him to His Highness.
Colonel and Mrs. C. Roadew Barn have left for Egypt, and will join the yacht "Miranda" at the end of March. They do not expect to returú till May.

div.head: SOCIETE ANONYME DES MAISONS ECONOMIQUES
div.p: Le Comité de défense des intérêts des loca taires vient de publier les statuts financiers de la future société anonyme des maisons éconc miques. En voici les principales dispositions:--
La Società Anonima delle Case Economiche sura son siège à Alexandrie. La durée de l Société est fixés à trente ans, mais cette pé riode pourra être renouvelée.

Le capital social sera de 200,000 L.B. divisées en 50,000 actions de 4 L.B. chacune. L'émission se fera par souscription publique et au pair. Ce capital pourra être augmenté par décision de l'assemblée générale.
Les titres ne deviendront transmissibles et au porteur qu'après leur paiement intégral. La responsabilité de chaque actionnaire est limitée à la valeur nominale des titres dont il est porteur.

Opérations de la société : Construction de maisons économiqus pour les ouvriers et les employés, à quelque nationalité ou religion. qu'ils appartiennent. Ces maisons devront être construites dans l'enceinte actuelle de la ville.

Le conseil d'administration sera composé de 9 membres élus par l'assemblée générale pour - une période de 3 ans: Ces membres seront ré- éligibles à l'expiration de leur mandat. Chaque année on procédera au renouvellement d'un tiers du conseil. Pour les deux premières années les sortants seront fixés par le sort et les années suivantes par rang d'ancienneté. Chaque administrateur devra mettre en dépôt dans la caisse de la société au moins 50 actions. Pour que le conseil puisse valablement délibérer, cinq membres au moins devront être présents. Les décisions seront prises à la majorité absolue des voix et en cas d'égalité de suffrages, la voix du président sera prépondérante. Le conseil d'administration jouira des pouvoirs les plus étendus: il nommera les employés, fixera leurs salaires, les révoquera, établira les règle ments intérieurs, autorisera les contrats, los transactions de toute sorte et les poursuites judiciaires, étudiera toutes les propositions faits à la société, conférera des procurations et établira le bilan. Bien que les membres du conseil ne contractent du fait de leur gestion aucune obligation personnelle, ils seront, toutefois, responsables de l'exécution du mand t qu'ils auront assumé.

Chaque mois le Conseil d'Administration nommera dans son sein un administrateur dé légué chargé de l'expédition des affaires courantes et de l'exécution des décisions prises par le conseil. Il représenters, en outre, la société vis à vis des tiers et en justice.

Le Gouvernement Egyptien aura la faculté de nommer un commissaire gouvernemental pour faire partie du Conseil d'Administration et exercer sur les comptes un contrôle minutieux. De plus le Ministre des Finances pourra nommer tous les ans un délégué pour vérifier le bilan et la comptabilité et dresser un rap. port détaillé qui sera soumis aux actionnaires à l'assemblée générale.

Une assemblée générale aura lieu chaque année et toutes les fois que le conseil d'Administration le jugera nécessaire. Tout actionnaite porteur de 10 actions aura droit à un seal vote jusqu'à un maximum de 10 voix. Ce chiffre ne pourra jamais être dépassé, quelque soit le nombre de titres dont l'actionnaire est détenteur.

Le prix de location ne devra en aucun cas dépasser le 7% du coût de l'immeuble. Le 7% sera donel'intérêt brut accordéaux actionnaires De ce taux il faudra déduire les frais d'adminis tration et du fonds de réserve. Dans le cas où les appartements ne suffiraient pas à la demande,un comité formé du président du conseil ou d'un administrateur délégué et du commissaire gouvernemental feront choix des personnes les plus dignes d'intérêt. En cas de conflit le conseil se prononcera en dernier ressort Les locataires et le conseil d'administration devront pour tous différends, avant de recourir aux tribunaux, s'en référér à l'arbitrage du commissaire gouvernemental.

La répartition des bénéfices se fera de la manière suivante: 1° impôts et frais d'administration, 2 Entretien des immeubles, 3 Après les deux prélèvements ci-dessus, 5% pour le fonds de réserve. 4° 5% au conseil d'administration. 5 émoluments du cominissaire gouvernemental et du délégué du Ministre des Finances à fixer par le Conseil d'Ad ministration. Après libération des cinq charges qui viennent d'être énumérées, les bénéfices restants formeront le dividende net des actionnaires.

La fonds de réserve sera capitalisé au fur et à mesure et consacré à la construction de nouvelles maisons économiques dont l'intérêt sera versé aux actionnaires. En cas de liquidation. de la société, le capital du fonds de réserve fera retour aux actionnaires, après extinction des dettes de la "Società Anonima delle Case Economiche."

Si pour une cause on pour une autre, le fonds de réserve venait à être épuisé et le capital versé réduit aux 3/4, l'assemblée généralo serait immédiatement convoquée pour voir s'il. y a lieu de liquider la société ou d'en modifier les statuts. Les seuls tribunaux compétents en cas de conflit seront les tribunaux mixtes. Le conseil d'administration actuel restera en fonction jusqu'à l'assemblée générale de 1906. qui procèdera au renouvellement de 4 membres.

div.head: LE SCANDALE ALEXANDRIN.
div.p: Le Tribunal Consulaire d'Italie de notre ville a rendu le 13 et. son jugement dans le procès en séparation intenté par M. A. Ninci à sa femme, Mme Olga Constantinidis, pour, adultère avec le juge Constantin Dimaras, ex-président du Tribunal Consulaire et de la Cour d'Assi ses helléniques d'Alexandrie.
Hatons-nous de dire que ce jugement donne à M. Ninci l'entière et légitime satisfaction à laquelle il avait droit.

Le Tribunal a prononcé la séparation aux torts de Mme Olga Constantinidis pour adultère; il a fixé à P.T. 25 par jour la pension alimentaire à laquelle avait droit la défenderesse et a condamné cette dernière à tous les dépens, y compris les honoraires de Me Mario Colucci,avocat de M. Ninci.
Nous publierons prochainement le jugement in-extenso.
Municipalit Alexandri
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de dallage des rues Moussaferkana, El Helal et Sidi Daoud, et de deux ruelles près: du Mawazini.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE 40.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 28 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5b.p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour dallage rues Moussaferkana eto."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une Banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis au Service de la Comptabilité avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 28 février à midi.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY
Alexandrie, le 11 février 1905.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le Mardi 21 février courant de 11 h. a.m. à 1 h. p.m. et de 3h. au coucher du soleil, la Municipalité procèdera à la vente aux enchères publiques près des cimetières européens, sis à la Porte Kosette, d'une quantité de 2000 m3. environ des pierres extraites des terrains des fortifications divisée en lots de 40 à 100 m3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchère de 1% et déposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral à la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.
Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix jours, sous peine de folle euchère pour compte de l'adjudicataire.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY
Alexandrie, le 11 février 1905.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Menes" sailed yesterday
afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 4,850 bales cotton.
The Ellerman 8.8. "Anatolia" arrived at Liverpool from Alexandhia on Friday morning. The Westcott S.S." Perim" arrived here on Sunday evening from Antwerp, London, and Malta, with general cargo.
The Westcott 8.8. "Barcelona" sailed yester day evening hence direct for England with full cargo of cottonseed.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE-We would call the attention of persons interested in: Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-street EC., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINISTERS.
div.p: Pharaoh" sends to the "Morning Post" from the Royal Societies Club the following communication in favor of abolishing Egyp tian native, Ministers and Under Secretaries of State

"Redde Caesari quae sunt Caesaris. Thanks to Great Britain, Egypt has entered an era of prosperity aud wealth without precedent in her history. By the improvement and by the development of the irrigation system tie fertility of the Egyptian soil has been wonderfully increased, and large tracts of land that a few years ago only could not be cultivated are now producing fine crops. The railway system, which twenty years ago cousisted only in what was deemed strictly necessary for the conveyance and the convenience of the wealthier classes, covers now a considerable area, numer ous branch lines have been laid, railway fares have been reduced, so that the transport by rail has bee me easy, rapid, and cheap. With regard to trade, imports and exports have attained a high figure, as shown by the customs revenues, which are increasing from year to year. Companies have been formed for the working of mines in Upper Egypt, other companies are busy with agriculture, others are engaged in land speculations, foreign capital is pouring into the country, business transactions are easy all over the land.

By mentioning thus the main and most striking features of the prosperity of Egypt 1 merely intend to show the beneficial effects of the British occupation; but the object of my letter comes hereafter. From the highest official down to the humblest "fellah" every soul in the Nile Valley knows that the Egyptian Government is practically and exclusively exercis ed by the representativeut Great Britain, who is himself represented in each department by a British off cial, and that official is absolutely the sole effective head of the department. It des not require ich phraseology to enhance the advantages and the soundness of this state of things. Suffice it to say that no intelligent, honest, and straightforward Egyptian would ever dream of its change, especially if h remembers the gloomy days of the past. Under these circumstalices, and since the Egyptia affairs are managed in the right way by Briti-li officials as to ensure the welfare of the country and its population, one is at a loss to under: stand the reason for having native Ministers and Under Secretaries of State, wh, of utility whatever, are, as shown in the following list, a yearly burden to the Egyptian Budget of £E.23,000.
The Minister of the Interior...... L.E. 3,500) The Minister of Finance...
The Minister of Justice

The Minister for Public Works and Public
Instruction...
The Under Secretary of State (Interior) 1,500
The Under Secretary of State (Justice) 1,500
The Under Secretary of State (Foreign
Affairs).... The Under Secretary of the War Office 1,500 The Under Secretary for the Ministry of
Public Instruction ...
The Minister of Foreign Affairs has not been mentioned in the above list, being the effective head of his department, where there is no British official:

div.head: VAL-DE-TRAVERS COMPANY.
div.p: The Val de Travers Company has been established at Alexandria for the past three years, and under the able management of Mr. Mr. Miard it has obtained a large number of local contracts. As an instance of the succes of the company we culi the following para graph from a Calcutta contemporary of the 10th ulto.:Yesterday afternoon the Viceroy visited the portion of the Strand road.opposite the point where the Val-de-Travers Company are laying their asphalte. The Hon. R. T Greer, Chairman of the Corporation, Mr. W.B. McCabe, Mr. C. A. Giannacopuloy the repre sentative of Messrs. Glastone, Wyllie and Co., and the expert of the Val-de-Travers Com pany, Mr. Collaud, were present. Considering the suitability of asphalte pavement for a city like Calcutta, especially such portions a Barra Bazaar, it is hoped that the Viceroy's interest in the matter is evidence of a move ment in the direction of extending its use."

div.head: CAIRO AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
div.p: OPENING DAY.

At 2.30 p.m. yesterday, H.H. the Khedive augurated the Khedivial Agricultural Society's Stew, which was favored by warm and quietweather, a bright sun and last but not least -a great number of visitors. Besides the Khedive who stayed for some time and took great interest in the numerons exhibits-nearly all the representatives of the Powers, the Governor of Cairo, and several of the Ministers were present, and with them almost all the principal members of the Khedivial Agricultural Society. Among other visitors to the show we noticed Mr. and Mrs. Graham, Mr. Anthony, Mrs. Hunter, the Hon. A. and Mrs. Davey, Sir William and Lady Wille cks, Dainos Pasha, Mr. Allen, Mr. G. B. Alderson, Mr. Sibbald, Milhem Shaoour Bey and Miss Chacour.

The exhibition presented a very animated, not to say exciting scene. Messrs. Orenstein and Koppel's locomotive was running on the circular line of light railway laid down in front of the central hall, pulling a number of trucks and arousing the interest of numerous experts -and non-experts. All the machinery erected in the sheds was at work-pumps, grain clean. ers, decorticators, and diggers of every typeand the Cooper digger was showing its paces, turning in a marvellously short circle and runuing at a good speed on the roadway in front or the old sheds. In the central hall were the exhibits of cotton, cereals and poultry, admirably arranged and attractive exhibits. Another interesting feature, which we do not remember to have seen in previous shows, was Boniteau Bey's collection of insect pests and beneficial insects, the latter including one of the chief enemies of the locusts, a large black "Sphex" resembling a huge and hirsute wasp. A case containing locusts of the 1904 swarms in all stages from two hours' age to maturity was very interesting.

The exhibits of cotton and cereals were extremely good, the poultry-Beladi for the most part-made a good show, and there were any well-known names among the prizewinners. In our next issue we will publish the lists of the prizes and winners.
EXHIBITS REVIEWED.

The following is a description of the exhibits of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt) Ltd:- A Tangye's gas engine with suction producer plant, of 23 maximum B. H. P. The well-known arrangement of engine and plant combines the following advantages: No steam boiler or gas holder is required, so that there is no liability of explosion. It does not need onstant supervision, but requires to be attended to only for a few minutes every three or four hours. It occupies only a small amount of floor space and requires no foundation. The apparatus may be fixed indoors as there is no more danger from fire than with an ordinary stove. There is no risk of gas escaping, as it is generated by suction and below atmospheric pressure. There is great economy of fuel as cheap anthracite "peas" are used in the generator. It can be re-started, after being shut down for an hour or so, in a few minutes, and, even from a cold condition, from 15 to 20 minutes. Gas is generated only as it is required by the engine. No gas is blown or burnt twaste on light loads. It is smokeless and tree from smell. The fuel used, known as "anthracite peas," can be obtained easily in Alexandria at a very cheap rate. The fuel consumption does not exceed 0.9 lb. per B. H. P. per hour. On six hours' continuous test of Tangye's gas engine developing 22 B. H. P. working in conjunction with a "D" suction producer, the consumption of anthra cite peas was found to be as low as 0.785 per B. H. P. per hour.

One Tangye's 10 B.H.P. portable oil engine is bolted on steel girder frame and mounted on four travelling wheels, the two front wheels being carried by a swivelling carriage for convenience in moving about. The engine is fitted with a balanced crank shaft, oil splash guard, pressure pump, and oil reservoir for supplying the lamps, extended cowl for protecting the vaporiser and lamps from the weather, and a water circulating pump. A tank of large capauity for holding the cooling water is carried on the girder frame, and the water is forced through the jacket of the engine cylinder by the circulating pump to a cooling chamber, where it meets a current of cold air and after wards returns to the opposite end of the tank. The carriage is fitted with shafts, it has slipper and chain for use when travelling down hills, and a set of checks for fixing it in position when the engine is at work.

One seamless steel launch. Each side is made all of one plate pressed into shape by hydraulic pressure; all the plates are after wards galvanised, which will give them a very long life against the action of the sea water. It is fitted with a 10 B.H.P. petroleum engine. One Cooper patent steam digger No. 5. Thi is an invention for cultivating all kinds of soil by steam power. Briefly described, it consists of a machine which travels over the land at a rate of from one to two miles an hour, forking up and turning over the soil as it travelby means of a series of forks fixed on a rotating crank in the rear of the machine. The depth to which these forks will enter the soil is regulated by two shoes, which slide over the ground and allow the digging ear to rise or sink with the inequalities of the surface. The diggers are the result of experience gained in actual work during many years under greatly varying conditions and in all kinds of lands, from the hardest sun baked soil of South Africa and Egypt to the heaviest clay or lightest sand of England Under all circumstances, they are now justify ing their claim to be the most efficient cultivators ever made. The work done is similar to the best manual digging, the soil being taken up and exposed to the influence of the air, sun, or frost, in a manner which can only be equalled by carefully digging over every inch of land. Where deeprooted weeds abound, the diggers are the only machines which can suscessfully deal with them, pulling them to the surface instead of cutting the roots under ground and leaving them to grow again.

A distinctive and important feature of the Cooper digger lies in the fact that the power exerted in driving the forks into the land and turning the soil, is also useful in an equal degree in lifting the weight of the engine from the ground and propelling it forward. In all other methods of mechanical cultivation, this power is absolutely lost, and even tends to impede the engine. This cir cumstance explains the fact that the Cooper Digger will break up lands to any given degree of fiueness with half the consumption of coal and water of any machine on the market.

One of the greatest difficulties which have been met with in cultivating the land with a travelling engine is the length of time wasted in turning at the headlands. In some cases the engines have to be disconnected, and hitched on at the other end of the cultivator. Other machines have to back and manoeuvre to get into the return position. The Cooper digger alone can turn in its own length without stopping, the whole operation being completed in thirty seconds.

Another exhibit is theCochran patent boiler. This is a vertical boiler, aud in common with all vertical boilers, it possesses these most important advantages: Economy of floor space. It does not require any brickwork setting. Ali that is required is to set it on a hard level surface and it is ready for work. In addition to these advantages, it has also the following:- By its special arrangement of horizontal fine tubes, it has a large heating surface, thereby combining the advantages of the vertical boiler with the economy of the locomotive or multitubular boi er. At the same time it is wholly accessible for cleaning and examining inside, an advantage not usually possessed by other types of multitubular boilers. This is a point of extreme importance when only impure water is obtainable.

The Cochran boiler can be kept thoroughly c'ean inside, and consequently its efficiency is always maintained, and repairs seldom if ever necessary. Experience leads to the confident assertion: (a) that it is more economical than any other small boiler made; (b) that it is more durable and reliable than any other boiler; (e) that it is the easiest boiler to set to work, and the most economical to maintain; (d) that it is absolutely safe from explosion; (e) that it is the cheapest and best made boiler in the market.

Garrett's Engines. These engines are from the works of the well-known firm of Messrs. Richard Garrett aud Sous, of Leiston, estab lished in 1778, who have through five successive ge erations devoted themselves espe cially to the perfection of their engines, and to the establishment of an almost unequalled plant of labour-saving and other machinery if the highest class. The engines are fitted. with Garrett's patent corrugated fire-boxes. These fire-boxes are very elastic, which mean durable, and have about 22% more heating surface than the flat-topped boxes, and it must be borne in mind that experiments have proved that about half of the total evaporation of a boiler is carried out in the immediate vicinity of the fire box.

div.head: PERHAPS YOUR TROUBLE IS KIDNEY DISEASE.
div.p: Kidney disease comes on quietly-may have been in the system for years before the patient suspected the real cause of his trouble.. There may have been headaches, limb aches, neuralgia, sciatica, rheumatism, a nervous, irritable feeling, or a generally weak, tired, feeling, weak heart, swelling of the flesh, puffy eyes, etc.
He did not know that these were symptoms of kidney disease, and so he doctored the symptoms, and not the kidneys,

Thus the trouble kept growing worse, until disturbances of the water appeared, or there was gravel, or retention of urine, or backache -or some such plain sign of kidney trouble that there could be no doubt.

Dean's backache kidney pills should be taken at the first sign of anything wrong. There is no other safe way, because kidney diseases are the most dangerous of all, except consumption. Doan's pills strengthen the kid neys and help them to properly perform that most important of all functions-the filtering of the blood-help them to flush off, and carry away with the surplus water, all these impurities which the blood gathers up in its circuit of the body. In no other way can you be well. Doan's backache kidney pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists for P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes; or they may be had by post from the general agent for Egypt, Mr. Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil St., Mousky St., Cairo.

div.head: MARKET FOR EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: Mr. Henry J. Monson writes to us from London:-Before again leaving England for Egypt I have been making close enquiries into the business of Egyptian cotton in Manchester as I did last year. It is of the greatest importance to the cotton growers to know that it is very doubtful if the spindles recently put on to American will revert to Egyptian again. The Egyptian market is bad, the demand does not meet the increased production. If spindles are reverted from American to Egyptian, a greater competition will set in than ever before. The Federation of Master Cotton Spinners and the Bolton Master Cotton Spinners Association have amalgamated, and will now control over 30 million spindles. The future prosperity of Egypt, and the maintenance of the excessive high value put on land, depends on the move this association makes. If the spindles are reverted, the value put on land at this moment will prove to be entirely imaginary. I am of opinion that much of the land that has been put under cotton will revert again to sugar cane culture. Owing to the great development of cotton cultivation in other parts of the world, Egypt must endeavour to keep to the front. It is useless any one talking to spinners on the quality of Egyptian cotton surpassing all others, expecting a ready purchase and a high price, because the answer given will be a disappointment. I have visited the large wholesale houses in Nottingham and London, The position now is, "that our market looks "like failing us, and if not entirely then our "price obtained will be low owing to great "competition."The sooner we agriculturista get together and discuss this matter of endeavouring to enlarge the present market, seek other markets, or create new markets, the better it will be for our future prosperity. An Egyptian cotton growers' association should be formed at once. You, Sir, would be doing a great service to the country if you would select the names for a committee, with Alex andria as the central office.
